Description: Rim and body sherd, mended from two fragments, of Chian Simple Animal Style pottery chalice; cream slip; interior: reserved band at rim, glazed streaky black below; lotus flower in added white outline with added red centre; below, two white bands; exterior: narrow black band on top of rim; short diagonal stroke pattern between pairs of dilute bands; below, painted decoration consisting of sphinx (head with red hair and curlicue remaining), to left.
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Sanctuary of Aphrodite (Naukratis) (according to Ashmolean Museum register)
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Lemos describes this sherd as belonging to the first stage of the Group of the Simple Figures. Some sherds in this group have the double-edges saw pattern in the handle zone. In this instance, only the rim of the chalice remains. It should be mentioned that the vessels listed in Lemos's first Simple Figures Group that do not have the double-edged saw pattern consist only of small sherds. For parallels regarding the sphinx, see Oxford AN1896-1908-G.114.1 and Cambridge Fitzwilliam GR.86.1894.
Bibliographic references: Lemos 1991 / Archaic Pottery of Chios. The Decorated Styles (p. 130, p. 292, no. 904, pl. 121)
CVA Oxford II / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum Great Britain 9 Oxford fasicule 2 (p. 81, no. 13, pl. V)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GD.1216) (phase 2)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Ashmolean Museum, University of Oxford
